definition[0]: nerves are parts inside your body which look like threads and carry messages between the brain and other parts of the body
note[0]: trapped nerve British English,  pinched nerve American English (=a nerve that has been crushed between two muscles etc, causing pain)
example[0]: a condition which affects the nerves in the back
definition[1]: courage and confidence in a dangerous, difficult, or frightening situation
example[1]: It takes a lot of nerve to report a colleague for sexual harassment.
example[2]: Jensen would’ve won if he hadn’t lost his nerve.
example[3]: It’s hard to keep your nerve when people keep interrupting you.
example[4]: Not many people have the nerve to stand up and speak in front of a large audience.
example[5]: She finally found the nerve to tell him she wanted a divorce.
definition[2]: if you say someone has a nerve, you mean that they have done something unsuitable or impolite, without seeming to be embarrassed about behaving in this way
example[6]: He’s got a nerve asking for more money.
example[7]: ‘She didn’t say sorry or anything.’ ‘What a nerve!’
example[8]: She lets me do all the work, and then she has the nerve to criticize my cooking.
note[4]: have the nerve to do something
example[9]: She took a few deep breaths, trying to calm her nerves.
example[10]: She hoped that a cup of tea would soothe her nerves.
example[11]: He suffered from nerves and could no longer perform on stage.
example[12]: Suddenly she was wide awake, her nerves jangling.
example[13]: Quite a few of the students suffered from exam nerves.
example[14]: She always suffered from first-night nerves.
example[15]: His nerves were on edge as he entered the dark room.
example[16]: Everyone's nerves were frayed by the end of the week.
collocation[8]: somebody's nerves are stretched (to breaking point)
example[17]: Her nerves were stretched almost to breaking point as she waited.
example[18]: I was a bag of nerves during the interview.
example[19]: Just before the audition he was shaking with nerves.
collocation[11]: be in a state of nerves
example[20]: She was in such a state of nerves that she jumped at every noise.
example[21]: Harrison had an attack of nerves before the match.
heading[0]: – Meaning 3: courage and confidence in a dangerous, difficult, or frightening situation
example[22]: I just didn't have the nerve to tell them the truth.
collocation[13]: find the nerve to do something
example[23]: He couldn't find the nerve to ask her out.
example[24]: The team held their nerve and went on to win.
example[25]: I wanted to ask him the question, but I lost my nerve.
example[26]: The next few days would test their nerve to the limit.
example[27]: At the last moment, her nerve failed her.
example[28]: The police hoped his nerve would break and he'd give himself away.
collocation[17]: it takes nerve to do something
example[29]: It takes nerve to stand up for what you believe.
example[30]: They accused the government of a loss of nerve.
